abstract.para: This file provides documentation for the data file, 95bovhg1.dat, a comma delimited file containing vertical hydraulic gradient (VHG) measurements for Oksrukuyik creek and both the reference and fertilized zones of the Kuparuk river during the 1995 field season.

para.literalLayout: Open ended, known lengths of 3/4 inch CPVC were inserted into the stream bed by forcing a pry bar into the stream bed to a depth of the maximum depth allowed, typically 30-60 centimeters. The CPVC was then worked down into the hole and the pry bar removed, allowing the hole to cave in onto the sampler. The length of the sampler, still above the substrate, was measured and subtracted from the total length to find the depth of the sampler in the substrate (Z). Samplers were allowed to settle for a one week period before measurement for the VHG were made. Two wires were attached to a ruler with one end of the leads exposed with a two millimeter gap between the two wires. The other end of the leads were attached to a voltage mulitmeter set to measure resistance, upon contact with the water surface a "beep" was emitted. Exterior measurements to the water were made directly with a ruler(L1) and the probe was inserted into the sampler to determine the interior depth to water (L2). The VHG = (L2-L1)/Z. Negative values represent downwelling zones while positive values represent upwelling zones.

Notes: The variable, D/D for Distance on river is in reference to the top of the riffle. Use the ID and D-H variables (R=right, L=left and distance downstream) for more detailed positions. The variable, "Loc", refers: KR=Kuparuk Reference Zone, KF=Kuparuk Fertilized zone, OCR=Oksrukuyik Cr. Reference zone. River distances are in reference to the established river markings. Calculations: VHG = (L2-L1)/Z where: L1 = Depth to water inside the piezometer from the sampler top (centimeters). L2 = Depth to water outside the piezometer from the sampler top (centimeters). Z = Depth of piezometer into the substrate (centimeters).
